## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS

0606/12

Paper 1 Non- calculator

February/March 2025

2 hours

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 88]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 103, 787, 123]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 152, 675, 171]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 200, 687, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 243, 680, 272]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 687, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 345, 656, 363]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 364, 555, 397]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 438, 225, 456]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 429, 904, 470]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 476, 770, 515]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 546, 217, 563]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 545, 675, 585]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 622, 217, 638]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 621, 570, 700]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 732, 158, 749]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 730, 555, 780]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 821, 242, 839]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 816, 580, 892]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 72, 666, 90]]<|/det|>
<form>Calculators must not be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 104, 99, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 144, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
1 (a) On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y=4|x-1|\) and \(y=|3 x+2|\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 148, 831, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 518, 144, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 516, 477, 535]]<|/det|>
(b) Solve the inequality \(4|x-1| \leqslant|3 x+2|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
2

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 92, 880, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 335, 685, 352]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y=a \cos b x+c\) for \(-180^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 415, 367]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 346, 399]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 536, 97, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 536, 406, 553]]<|/det|>
3 The point \(A\) has coordinates \((-3,6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 552, 406, 568]]<|/det|>
The point \(B\) has coordinates \((7,-8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 737, 600]]<|/det|>
Given that the line \(A B\) is the diameter of a circle, find the equation of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 809, 110]]<|/det|>
4 The polynomial \(p\) is given by \(p(x)=a^{2} x^{3}+2 a x^{2}+a x+2\), where \(a\) is a positive integer. It is given that \(2 x+1\) is a factor of \(p(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 125, 144, 141]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 125, 312, 141]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 495, 144, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 495, 327, 512]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence factorise \(p(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 696, 144, 713]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 695, 664, 712]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence show that the equation \(p(x)=0\) has only one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 79, 99, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 81, 144, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 767, 100]]<|/det|>
5 (a) Write \(2 x^{2}-2 x+3\) in the form \(a\left(x+b\right)^{2}+c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 265, 532, 285]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 x^{2}-2 x+3\), for \(x \leqslant p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 298, 144, 315]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 297, 636, 316]]<|/det|>
(b) Write down the greatest value of \(p\) for which f has an inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 421, 144, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 420, 534, 438]]<|/det|>
(c) Using this value of \(p\), write down the range of f .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 560, 144, 577]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 559, 541, 577]]<|/det|>
(d) Using this value of \(p\), find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 84, 99, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 524, 103]]<|/det|>
6 It is given that \(\tan \theta=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\) and \(180^{\circ}<\theta<360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 117, 144, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 116, 344, 133]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the value of \(\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 303, 144, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 303, 339, 320]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(\sin \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 457, 144, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 454, 406, 472]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the value of \(\sec \theta+\cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 477, 697, 510]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a+b \sqrt{c}}{\sqrt{5}}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 74, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
7

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 97, 902, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 433, 918, 470]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y=\frac{5}{x+1}+2\) and part of the line \(y=2 x+1\) intersecting at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 485, 144, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 484, 361, 501]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the coordinates of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 473, 91]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the exact area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 485, 91]]<|/det|>
8 The first term of a geometric progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 88, 574, 106]]<|/det|>
This geometric progression has a positive common ratio \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 532, 137]]<|/det|>
The first term of an arithmetic progression is also 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 625, 152]]<|/det|>
This arithmetic progression has a negative common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 845, 199]]<|/det|>
The second term of the geometric progression is the same as the fourth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 915, 214]]<|/det|>
The third term of the geometric progression is the same as the sixth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 229, 144, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 228, 364, 246]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the values of \(r\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 725, 144, 742]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 724, 682, 742]]<|/det|>
(b) Determine whether the geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 84, 107, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 78, 468, 102]]<|/det|>
10 The point \(P\) lies on the curve \(y=\left(5 x+2\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 100, 325, 116]]<|/det|>
The \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is 5 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 115, 694, 131]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at \(P\) intersects the line \(x+y=11\) at the point \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 131, 626, 147]]<|/det|>
The point \(R\) is the reflection of \(Q\) in the tangent to the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 163, 323, 178]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 454, 90]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 92, 831, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 336, 411, 354]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 356, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
The point \(M\) is the midpoint of \(O B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 374, 395, 392]]<|/det|>
The point \(N\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{ON} = 3 \overrightarrow{NA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 395, 473, 412]]<|/det|>
The lines \(B N\) and \(A M\) intersect at the point \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 413, 396, 431]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{B X}=\lambda \overrightarrow{B N}\), where \(\lambda\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 432, 395, 450]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{M X}=\mu \overrightarrow{M A}\), where \(\mu\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 464, 144, 480]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 462, 410, 480]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\overrightarrow{O X}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 81, 144, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 78, 411, 97]]<|/det|>
(b) Find \(\overrightarrow{O X}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 500, 144, 516]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 498, 421, 516]]<|/det|>
(c) Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[334, 916, 664, 932]]<|/det|>
Question 12 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 109, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 76, 334, 95]]<|/det|>
12 It is given that \(y=x \mathrm{e}^{3 x+2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 108, 144, 125]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 103, 230, 131]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 356, 144, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 345, 352, 378]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence find \(\int x \mathrm{e}^{3 x+2} \mathrm{~d} x\).
